docs.lead_paragraph: "The Age of AIDS" is a gripping two-part, four-hour "Frontline" documentary that begins on Tuesday night on PBS.

headline.main: The Documentary 'The Age of AIDS' Begins on PBS
headline.kicker: TV Review | 'Frontline: The Age of AIDS'
headline.print_headline: The Epidemic as Avalanche: A Two-Part Series Documents 25 Years of AIDS
headline.content_kicker: TV Review | 'Frontline: The Age of AIDS'

docs.snippet: "The Age of AIDS" is a gripping two-part, four-hour "Frontline" documentary that begins on Tuesday night on PBS.

docs.lead_paragraph: There's Elizabeth Taylor, pretty in pink, and beside her Nancy Reagan, elegant in white, wearing a cautious version of her adoring-wife gaze. Ms. Taylor looks pleased, too. It is 1987, and at her invitation, six years into the AIDS epidemic, President Ronald Reagan is making his first -- and, as it turned out, only -- speech on the subject. The scene is from ''The Age of AIDS,'' a gripping (eventually) two-part, four-hour ''Frontline'' documentary that begins tonight on PBS. It doesn't offer a lot of movie star scenes like that, but it's loaded with drama. The most bizarre juxtaposition has to be Bono, of the rock group U2, quoting Scripture to Senator Jesse Helms.

headline.main: The Epidemic as Avalanche: A Two-Part Series Documents 25 Years of AIDS

docs.abstract: Anita Gates reviews PBS program Frontline: The Age of AIDS; photo (M)
